messages.title: Together let's build a fairer Britain
messages.content: It’s a real privilege to have been chosen as your Labour candidate for Shipley in the General Election on Thursday 8 June. I was born into a working-class family in Dorset and worked as a stockman on a farm before becoming the first member of my family to go to university. In 2008, I moved to West Yorkshire to work as a medical scientist at Leeds University, where I teach and research on neurological diseases in children, in partnership with the NHS – I’m not a career politician, and can bring a fresh perspective from outside politics. I look forward to discussing Labour’s vision for a fairer Britain with you, as I go from door to door in the coming weeks. Dr Steve Clapcote – Labour Parliamentary Candidate for Shipley

keyPolicies.policyDescription: Labour government will end the privatisation of our NHS and provide the funding our NHS and social care system desperately needs.
We’ll build more than one million affordable houses and council homes across the country, while also giving private renters more rights.

keyPolicies.policyTitle: A decent education for our children
keyPolicies.policyDescription: We’ll create a new National Education Service, open to all throughout their lives, and focus on what matters in our schools – reducing class sizes and raising teaching standards.
We promise no tax rises for 95% of earners, an end to exploitative zero-hour contracts, action to close the gender pay gap, and a real Living Wage of £10 an hour.
We’ll drive the expansion of the green industries and jobs of the future, and preserve and enhance our environmental standards and protections.

keyPolicies.policyTitle: A Brexit that protects jobs and the economy
keyPolicies.policyDescription: Labour will put the interests of working people first in the Brexit negotiations.

mentions.candidate: Dr Steve Clapcote - Labour Parliamentary Candidate for Shipley

leaflet.personalStatement: It’s a real privilege to have been chosen as your Labour candidate for Shipley in the General Election on Thursday 8 June. I was born into a working-class family in Dorset and worked as a stockman on a farm before becoming the first member of my family to go to university. In 2008, I moved to West Yorkshire to work as a medical scientist at Leeds University, where I teach and research on neurological diseases in children, in partnership with the NHS – I’m not a career politician, and can bring a fresh perspective from outside politics. I look forward to discussing Labour’s vision for a fairer Britain with you, as I go from door to door in the coming weeks.

examples: We promise no tax rises for 95% of earners.
I look forward to discussing Labour’s vision for a fairer Britain with you.
We’ll build more than one million affordable houses and council homes across the country, while also giving private renters more rights.
Labour government will end the privatisation of our NHS and provide the funding our NHS and social care system desperately needs.
We’ll create a new National Education Service, open to all throughout their lives, and focus on what matters in our schools – reducing class sizes and raising teaching standards.
We promise no tax rises for 95% of earners, an end to exploitative zero-hour contracts, action to close the gender pay gap, and a real Living Wage of £10 an hour.
We’ll drive the expansion of the green industries and jobs of the future, and preserve and enhance our environmental standards and protections.
Labour will put the interests of working people first in the Brexit negotiations.

In 2008, I moved to West Yorkshire to work as a medical scientist at Leeds University, where I teach and research on neurological diseases in children, in partnership with the NHS – I’m not a career politician, and can bring a fresh perspective from outside politics.
